ygData.subject: Re: Need some clarification on one line in the starting genome file
ygData.msgSnippet: ... That appears to be a mistake.  Those should indeed be innovation numbers and therefore should never be the same for two different genes in the same genome.

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "aimike002" <aimike002@...> wrote:
>
> Need so=
me clarification on one line in the starting genome file
> 
> 
> From JNEAT=
 xor:
> 
>  genomestart  1
>  trait 1 0.1 0 0 0 0 0 0 0
>  trait 2 0.2 0 0 =
0 0 0 0 0
>  trait 3 0.3 0 0 0 0 0 0 0
>  node 1 0 1 1
>  node 2 0 1 1
>  n=
ode 3 0 1 3
>  node 4 0 0 2
>  gene 1 1 4 0.0 0 1 0 1
>  gene 2 2 4 0.0 0 2=
 0 1
>  gene 3 3 4 0.0 0 3 0 1
>  genomeend 1
> 
> Looking at then gene lin=
es and Cross referencing to Ken's Neatdoc.ps
> file, I make the first gene =
line as:
> 
> 
> gene 1(link gene number) 1(from) 4(to) 0.0(weight) 0(recur=
 flag? -
> ignore) 1(innov number) 0(redundant-ignore) 1(enable bit)
> 
> S=
o far , so good, but when I look at another example included with
> JNEAT, =
for the parity example I get:
> 
>  genomestart  1
> [...]
>  gene 1 1 5 0.=
0 0 1     0 1
>  gene 2 2 5 0.0 0 2     0 1
>  gene 3 3 5 0.0 0 1(X1) 0 1
>=
  gene 1 4 5 0.0 0 2(X2) 0 1
>  genomeend 1
> 
> 
> If the elements marked =
X1 and X2 are starting innovations , I was
> expecting '3' and '4' respecti=
vely.
> 
> Please can someone clarify what that digit 3rd from the end mean=
s.
> 
> Thanks
> 
> Mike
>

That appears to be a mistake.  Those should ind=
eed be innovation 
numbers and therefore should never be the same for two d=
ifferent 
genes in the same genome.  

Also, the first number after "gene" =
is a trait number used to assign 
traits to genes.  It should have no effec=
t.

ken
